note.p: Birth: 1 High Row, Kensington, London, England (14 April 1857)
Research Field: Neurosurgery, neurophysiology, pathology, social reform

Career: Brown Professor of Pathology, University of London (1884-1890); Surgeon, National Hospital for Paralysed and Epileptic, London (1886); Assistant Surgeon, University College Hospital, London; Surgeon, University College Hospital (1900); resigned (1906); studied the thyoid gland and later became involved in medical politics and social problems; joined the Army (World War 1) and served in Egypt and Mesopotamia; died of sunstroke
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc Series B 1919-1920 vol 91 pp xliv-xlviii signed by F W M
